awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Mobile Manipulation Hospital Service Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project on hospital service robots is improving the quality of care in hospital systems that are under increased pressure to provide high-quality patient-centric care while functioning as profitable businesses. Hospitals face a shortage of qualified nurses and high rates of nurse turnover. Nurses play a critical role in communicating care plans, educating patients, and guarding against medical errors. The amount of time they spend in direct care activities is a key determinant of patient satisfaction, better patient outcomes, fewer errors, and shorter lengths of stay. In the face of nursing shortages across the U.S., it is increasingly important to have nurses performing at the 'top of their license'. Reducing the amount of time they spend on non-nursing tasks is crucial to this goal. Automation could address these challenges and labor shortage by allowing clinical staff to focus on providing skilled care. The proposed project aims to develop technology that is general-purpose enough to transfer to other markets, such as long term care facilities and, eventually, individual consumers. Robots that perform assistive tasks in homes could increase the feasibility of independent living for many older adults.


The proposed project will establish the technical and commercial feasibility of developing hospital service robots that act as assistants on acute care units, enabling nurses to spend more time at the bedside with patients. This project will make technical advances along three dimensions: the ability of the proposed robot to autonomously navigate within nursing units and across the hospital (navigation capabilities); to easily adapt its manipulation skills to specific tasks and to physical characteristics of a particular hospital/unit (adaptive learning of manipulation skills); and to work alongside humans in a socially acceptable manner, including appropriate navigation in crowded hallways, speech, and eye gaze behaviors that communicate the robot's intentions (socially intelligent interoperability). The team intends to collaborate closely with a single partner hospital to iteratively improve the reliability and robustness of the artificial intelligence software suite developed with NSF funding and to deploy production-quality versions of the three core competencies. The final 6 months will involve a long-term deployment, with the robot autonomously working on an acute care unit of the partner hospital. The impact of the robot on unit staff and workflows will be documented, with the ultimate goal of developing a service robot that hospital staff view as a competent member of the care team.

por.por_cntn:
Diligent Robotics is bringing hospital service robots to market. Our robots are designed to help hospitals bring down operational costs through process automation, and get their staff performing at the top of the license by having robots to do some of the fetch and deliver tasks that take clinicians away from patient-centered care.

Moxi, our first robot teammate in the field today, works in hospitals to help clinical staff with non-patient-facing tasks so they have more time for patient care.  With up to 30% of a care team member’s time spent on fetching and delivering items for their patients, Moxi is designed to complete routine tasks and give back the precious resource of time to nurses and hospital staff. 

With nurse and staff shortages at an all-time high even before the onset of COVID-19, Diligent’s core technology enables Moxi to help hospitals run 24/7 by assisting clinical staff with non-patient-facing tasks like: 

  • Delivering lab samples that are normally hand-delivered.

  • Running patient supplies and items that may have been left for a patient at the front desk.

  • Fetching items from central supply that are not normally stocked on the patient care units.

  • Distributing PPE and lightweight equipment in a just-in-time-fashion so that hospitals can make efficient use of these limited resources; and, 

  • Delivering medications that would normally be hand carried.

Nurses are the last line of defense in patient care, and all of these are examples of the “one-off” tasks that fall onto their plates on a daily basis. While each of them may only happen every once and awhile, they add up to hours taken away from the bedside every shift. As hospitals and nursing units start to automate some of these tasks with Moxi, it means nurses and care team members can reallocate their time towards patient care and practice at the top of their license.

One-off tasks are not only inefficient but leave RNs open to interruptions, increasing the risk of errors. More broadly, problems with employee engagement and turnover are a major challenge facing hospital leaders. Enabling clinicians to focus on clinical problem solving will improve job satisfaction, and ultimately positively impact patient care.

The technical objectives of our Phase IIb proposal are focused on interoperability between our robot systems and hospital software infrastructure, and on exploring opportunities for Moxi to perform similar materials management tasks in the operating room (OR) setting.  

Our research into OR settings  highlighted the continued need for improved fetch and carry tasks as well as the development of  automated request solutions to support these tasks.  Such workflows include patient belongings, linen deliveries, and medications required for discharge. The reduction of time spent on lesser skilled tasks ultimately improves both patient care by returning time to nurses to spend with their patients, and profitability for hospital systems by creating more efficient workflows in areas such as the pharmacy, lab, and other ancillary departments as well. These findings are having a direct impact on our product roadmap and are workflows we plan to implement with a number of our clients in the future.


On the interoperability front, we worked with our client Medical City Healthcare to identify Moxi delivery workflows for integration. Prior to EMR integration, robot support tasks must be scheduled for specific times of day, or directly requested by a clinician. With EMR integration we now remove the need for a nurse to notice the physician order and actively request Moxi to go fetch an item. We are excited to see this feature in daily use, and to start to identify more Moxi workflows that can be automatically triggered by the EMR. The future work around these use cases will shape some of the biggest milestones that we have on our product roadmap for 2022-23.
